entities.description: Philippe de Champaigne was a Brabançon-born French Baroque era painter, a major exponent of the French school. He was a founding member of the Académie de peinture et de sculpture in Paris, the premier art institution in France in the eighteenth century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Innocent XI (b. 1611)

entities.title: Pope Innocent XI
entities.description: Pope Innocent XI, born Benedetto Odescalchi, was Pope from 21 September 1676 to his death on August 12, 1689. He is known in Budapest as the "Saviour of Hungary".

heading: Deaths
txt: Peregrine Bertie, 3rd Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, English general and politician, Lord Lieutenant of Lincolnshire (b. 1714)

entities.title: Peregrine Bertie, 3rd Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven
entities.description: General Peregrine Bertie, 3rd Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, styled Lord Willoughby de Eresby from 1715 to 1723 and Marquess of Lindsey from 1735 to 1742 was the son of Peregrine Bertie, 2nd Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Lincolnshire
entities.description: The Lord-Lieutenant of Lincolnshire is the British monarch's personal representative in the county of Lincolnshire. Historically, the lord-lieutenant was responsible for organising the county's militia. In 1871, the lord-lieutenant's responsibility over the local militia was removed. However, it was not until 1921 that they formally lost the right to call upon able-bodied men to fight when needed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mikhail Kamensky, Russian field marshal (b. 1738)

entities.title: Mikhail Kamensky
entities.description: Count Mikhail Fedotovich Kamensky was a Russian Field Marshal prominent in the Catherinian wars and the Napoleonic campaigns.

heading: Deaths
txt: Étienne Louis Geoffroy, French pharmacist and entomologist (b. 1725)

entities.title: Étienne Louis Geoffroy
entities.description: Étienne Louis Geoffroy was a French entomologist and pharmacist. He was born in Paris and died in Soissons. He followed the binomial nomenclature of Carl von Linné and devoted himself mainly to beetles.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Stewart, Viscount Castlereagh, Irish-English politician, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (b. 1769)

entities.title: Robert Stewart, Viscount Castlereagh
entities.description: Robert Stewart, 2nd Marquess of Londonderry,, usually known as Lord Castlereagh, derived from the courtesy title Viscount Castlereagh by which he was styled from 1796 to 1821, was an Anglo-Irish statesman. As British Foreign Secretary, from 1812 he was central to the management of the coalition that defeated Napoleon. He was the principal British diplomat at the Congress of Vienna. Castlereagh was

entities.title: Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs
entities.description: The secretary of state for foreign, Commonwealth and development affairs, commonly known as the foreign secretary, is a senior minister of the Crown within the Government of the United Kingdom, and head of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office. As one of the four Great Offices of State, the foreign secretary is a senior member of the British Cabinet.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Blake, English poet and painter (b. 1757)

entities.title: William Blake
entities.description: William Blake was an English poet, painter, and printmaker. Largely unrecognised during his lifetime, Blake is now considered a seminal figure in the history of the poetry and visual arts of the Romantic Age. What he called his prophetic works were said by 20th-century critic Northrop Frye to form "what is in proportion to its merits the least read body of poetry in the English language". His visu

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Sapinaud de La Rairie, French general (b. 1760)

entities.title: Charles Sapinaud de La Rairie
entities.description: Charles Henri Félicité Sapinaud de la Rairie was a French soldier and Vendéen general during the war in the Vendée.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Stephenson, English engineer and academic (b. 1781)

entities.title: George Stephenson
entities.description: George Stephenson was a British civil engineer and mechanical engineer. Renowned as the "Father of Railways", Stephenson was considered by the Victorians a great example of diligent application and thirst for improvement. Self-help advocate Samuel Smiles particularly praised his achievements. His chosen rail gauge, sometimes called 'Stephenson gauge', was the basis for the 4 feet 8 1⁄2 inches (1.4

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Gallatin, Swiss-American ethnologist, linguist, and politician, 4th United States Secretary of the Treasury (b. 1761)

entities.title: Albert Gallatin
entities.description: Abraham Alfonse Albert Gallatin, born de Gallatin was an American politician, diplomat, ethnologist and linguist. Biographer Nicholas Dungan states he was "America's Swiss Founding Father." He is known for being the founder of New York University and for serving in the Democratic-Republican Party at various federal elective and appointed positions across four decades. He represented Pennsylvania i

entities.title: United States Secretary of the Treasury
entities.description: The United States secretary of the treasury is the head of the United States Department of the Treasury, which is concerned with all financial and monetary matters relating to the federal government, and, until 2003, also included several major federal law enforcement agencies. The secretary of the treasury is the principal economic advisor to the president of the United States and plays a critica

heading: Deaths
txt: Eliphalet Remington, American inventor and businessman, founded Remington Arms (b. 1793)

entities.title: Eliphalet Remington
entities.description: Eliphalet Remington founded what is now known as the Remington Arms Co., L.L.C. Originally the company was known as E. Remington followed by E. Remington & Son and then E. Remington and Sons.

entities.title: Remington Arms
entities.description: Remington Arms Company, LLC is a defunct American manufacturer of firearms and ammunition, and it was the largest rifle manufacturer in North America according to the ATF statistics in 2015. Founded in 1816 by Eliphalet Remington in Ilion, New York, it was one of the oldest gun makers in the US and claimed to be the oldest factory in the US that still made its original product. Remington was the l

heading: Deaths
txt: Sakuma Shōzan, Japanese scholar and politician (b. 1811)

entities.title: Sakuma Shōzan
entities.description: Sakuma Shōzan  sometimes called Sakuma Zōzan, was a Japanese politician and scholar of the Edo period.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Jackson Hooker, English botanist and academic (b. 1785)

entities.title: William Jackson Hooker
entities.description: Sir William Jackson Hooker was an English botanist and botanical illustrator, who became the first director of Kew when in 1831 it was recommended to be placed under state ownership as a botanic garden. At Kew he founded the Herbarium and enlarged the gardens and arboretum. The standard author abbreviation Hook. is used to indicate this person as the author when citing a botanical name.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Russell Lowell, American poet and critic (b. 1819)

entities.title: James Russell Lowell
entities.description: James Russell Lowell was an American Romantic poet, critic, editor, and diplomat. He is associated with the Fireside Poets, a group of New England writers who were among the first American poets that rivaled the popularity of British poets. These writers usually used conventional forms and meters in their poetry, making them suitable for families entertaining at their fireside.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Chamberlain, American colonel (b. 1841)

entities.title: Thomas Chamberlain (soldier)
entities.description: Thomas Davee Chamberlain was the Lieutenant Colonel of the 20th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment during the American Civil War, the brother of Union general Joshua L. Chamberlain, the Colonel of the 20th Maine Infantry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wilhelm Steinitz, Austrian chess player and theoretician (b. 1836)

entities.title: Wilhelm Steinitz
entities.description: William Steinitz was an Austrian and later American chess player, and the first official World Chess Champion, from 1886 to 1894. He was also a highly influential writer and chess theoretician.

heading: Deaths
txt: Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld, Finnish-Swedish botanist, geologist, mineralogist, and explorer (b. 1832)

entities.title: Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld
entities.description: Nils Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld was a Finland-Swedish aristocrat, geologist, mineralogist and Arctic explorer. He was a member of the prominent Finland-Swedish Nordenskiöld family of scientists and held the title of a friherre (baron).

heading: Deaths
txt: William Renshaw, English tennis player (b. 1861)

entities.title: William Renshaw
entities.description: William Charles Renshaw was a British tennis player active during the late 19th century, who was ranked world No. 1. He won twelve Major titles during his career. A right-hander, he was known for his power and technical ability which put him ahead of competition at the time. Renshaw shared the all-time male record of seven Wimbledon singles titles with American Pete Sampras until 2017 when Roger F

heading: Deaths
txt: John Philip Holland, Irish engineer, designed HMS Holland 1 (b. 1840)

entities.title: John Philip Holland
entities.description: John Philip Holland was an Irish engineer who developed the first submarine to be formally commissioned by the US Navy, and the first Royal Navy submarine, Holland 1.

entities.title: HMS Holland 1
entities.description: Holland 1 was the first submarine commissioned by the Royal Navy, the first in a six-boat batch of the Holland-class submarine. She was lost in 1913 while under tow to the scrapyard following decommissioning. Recovered in 1982, she was put on display at the Royal Navy Submarine Museum, Gosport. Her battery bank found in the boat was discovered to be functional after being cleaned and recharged.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Thompson, American archer (b. 1848)

entities.title: William Thompson (archer)
entities.description: William Henry Thompson was an American archer who competed in the early twentieth century. He won two bronze medals in Archery at the 1904 Summer Olympics in Missouri in the double York round, when Robert Williams won silver and his second bronze in the double American round. In the team competition he won the gold medal. He was born in Calhoun, Georgia and died in Seattle, Washington.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pyotr Boborykin, Russian playwright and journalist (b. 1836)

entities.title: Pyotr Boborykin
entities.description: Pyotr Dmitryevich Boborykin was a Russian writer, playwright, and journalist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Griffith, Irish journalist and politician, 3rd President of Dáil Éireann (b. 1871)

entities.title: Arthur Griffith
entities.description: Arthur Joseph Griffith was an Irish writer, newspaper editor and politician who founded the political party Sinn Féin. He led the Irish delegation at the negotiations that produced the 1921 Anglo-Irish Treaty, and served as President of Dáil Éireann from January 1922 until his death in August 1922.

entities.title: President of Dáil Éireann
entities.description: The President of Dáil Éireann was the leader of the revolutionary Irish Republic of 1919–1922. The office was created in the Dáil Constitution adopted by Dáil Éireann, the parliament of the Republic, at its first meeting in January 1919. This provided that the president was elected by the Dáil as head of a cabinet called the Ministry of Dáil Éireann. During this period, Ireland was deemed part of

heading: Deaths
txt: Sándor Bródy, Hungarian journalist and author (b. 1863)

entities.title: Sándor Bródy (writer)
entities.description: Sándor Bródy was a Hungarian author and journalist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leoš Janáček, Czech composer and educator (b. 1854)

entities.title: Leoš Janáček
entities.description: Leoš Janáček was a Czech composer, musical theorist, folklorist, publicist and teacher. He was inspired by Moravian and other Slavic folk music to create an original, modern musical style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hendrik Petrus Berlage, Dutch architect, designed the Beurs van Berlage (b. 1856)

entities.title: Hendrik Petrus Berlage
entities.description: Hendrik Petrus Berlage was a prominent Dutch architect.

entities.title: Beurs van Berlage
entities.description: The Beurs van Berlage is a building on the Damrak, in the centre of Amsterdam. It was designed as a commodity exchange by architect Hendrik Petrus Berlage and constructed between 1896 and 1903. It influenced many modernist architects, in particular functionalists and the Amsterdam School. It is now used as a venue for concerts, exhibitions and conferences.

heading: Deaths
txt: Friedrich Schottky, German mathematician and academic (b. 1851)

entities.title: Friedrich Schottky
entities.description: Friedrich Hermann Schottky was a German mathematician who worked on elliptic, abelian, and theta functions and introduced Schottky groups and Schottky's theorem. He was born in Breslau, Germany and died in Berlin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikolai Triik, Estonian painter, illustrator, and academic (b. 1884)

entities.title: Nikolai Triik
entities.description: Nikolai Voldemar Triik was an Estonian Modernist painter, graphic artist, printmaker and professor. His work displays elements of Symbolism and Expressionism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Freeman Freeman-Thomas, 1st Marquess of Willingdon, English soldier and politician, 56th Governor General of Canada (b. 1866)

entities.title: Freeman Freeman-Thomas, 1st Marquess of Willingdon
entities.description: Freeman Freeman-Thomas, 1st Marquess of Willingdon, was a British Liberal politician and administrator who served as Governor General of Canada, the 13th since Canadian Confederation, and as Viceroy and Governor-General of India, the country's 22nd.

entities.title: Governor General of Canada
entities.description: The governor general of Canada is the federal viceregal representative of the Canadian monarch, currently Queen Elizabeth II. The Queen, as a political sovereign, is shared equally with the 15 other Commonwealth realms and the 10 provinces of Canada, but she physically resides predominantly in her oldest and most populous realm, the United Kingdom. The Queen, on the advice of her Canadian prime mi

heading: Deaths
txt: Bobby Peel, English cricketer and umpire (b. 1857)

heading: Deaths
txt: Vittorio Sella, Italian photographer and mountaineer (b. 1859)

entities.title: Vittorio Sella
entities.description: Vittorio Sella was an Italian photographer and mountaineer, whose photographs of mountains are regarded as some of the finest ever made.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., American lieutenant and pilot (b. 1915)

entities.title: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.
entities.description: Joseph Patrick Kennedy Jr. was the eldest of the nine children born to Joseph P. Kennedy Sr. (1888–1969) and Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy (1890–1995). A US Navy lieutenant, he was killed in action during World War II while serving as a land-based patrol bomber pilot, and posthumously awarded the Navy Cross.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Bergelson, Ukrainian author and playwright (b. 1884)

entities.title: David Bergelson
entities.description: David Bergelson was a Yiddish language writer born in the Russian Empire. He lived for a time in Berlin, Germany before moving to the Soviet Union following the Nazi rise to power in Germany. He was a victim of the post-war antisemitic "rootless cosmopolitan" campaign and one of those executed on the Night of the Murdered Poets.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Mann, German author and critic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1875)

entities.title: Thomas Mann
entities.description: Paul Thomas Mann was a German novelist, short story writer, social critic, philanthropist, essayist, and the 1929 Nobel Prize in Literature laureate. His highly symbolic and ironic epic novels and novellas are noted for their insight into the psychology of the artist and the intellectual. His analysis and critique of the European and German soul used modernized versions of German and Biblical stor

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: James B. Sumner, American chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1887)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Mike O'Neill, Irish-American baseball player and manager (b. 1877)

entities.title: Mike O'Neill (baseball)
entities.description: Michael Joyce O'Neill was a starting pitcher and left fielder in Major League Baseball. From 1901 through 1907, he played for the St. Louis Cardinals (1901–04) and Cincinnati Reds (1907). O'Neill batted and threw right-handed. A native of Maam, Ireland, he played as Michael Joyce in his 1901 rookie year with the Cardinals.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ian Fleming, English spy, journalist, and author (b. 1908)

entities.title: Ian Fleming
entities.description: Ian Lancaster Fleming was a British writer, journalist and naval intelligence officer who is best known for his James Bond series of spy novels. Fleming came from a wealthy family connected to the merchant bank Robert Fleming & Co., and his father was the Member of Parliament for Henley from 1910 until his death on the Western Front in 1917. Educated at Eton, Sandhurst and, briefly, the universiti

heading: Deaths
txt: Artur Alliksaar, Estonian poet and author (b. 1923)

entities.title: Artur Alliksaar
entities.description: Artur Alliksaar was an Estonian poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Esther Forbes, American historian and author (b. 1891)

entities.title: Esther Forbes
entities.description: Esther Louise Forbes was an American novelist, historian and children's writer who received the Pulitzer Prize and the Newbery Medal. She was the first woman elected to membership in the American Antiquarian Society.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Rudolf Hess, Swiss physiologist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1881)

entities.title: Walter Rudolf Hess
entities.description: Walter Rudolf Hess was a Swiss physiologist who won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1949 for mapping the areas of the brain involved in the control of internal organs. He shared the prize with Egas Moniz.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Ziegler, German chemist and engineer, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1898)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: John Williams, English motorcycle racer (b. 1946)

entities.title: John Williams (motorcyclist)
entities.description: John Williams was an English motorcycle short-circuit road racer who also entered selected Grands Prix on the near-continent. He mostly raced as a 'privateer' having a personal sponsor, Gerald Brown. Williams died in Northern Ireland, following an accident when racing at an event held on closed public roads near Dundrod.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernst Boris Chain, German-Irish biochemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1906)

entities.title: Ernst Boris Chain
entities.description: Ernst Boris Chain was a German-born British biochemist, co-recipient of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his work on penicillin.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Fonda, American actor (b. 1905)

entities.title: Henry Fonda
entities.description: Henry Jaynes Fonda was an American film and stage actor who had a career that spanned five decades in Hollywood. Fonda cultivated a strong, appealing screen image in several films now considered to be classics, earning one Academy Award for Best Actor on two nominations.

heading: Deaths
txt: Salvador Sánchez, Mexican boxer (b. 1959)

heading: Deaths
txt: Theodor Burchardi, German admiral (b. 1892)

entities.title: Theodor Burchardi
entities.description: Theodor Burchardi was an Admiral with the Kriegsmarine during World War II and recipient of the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves of Nazi Germany. He was responsible for organising the evacuation of 2 million people from Courland and Eastern Prussia at the end of World War II in Operation Hannibal and the Evacuation of East Prussia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ladi Kwali, Nigerian potter (b. 1925)

entities.title: Ladi Kwali
entities.description: Ladi Kwali, OON, MBE was a Nigerian potter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kyu Sakamoto, Japanese singer-songwriter (b. 1941)

entities.title: Kyu Sakamoto
entities.description: Kyu Sakamoto  was a Japanese singer and actor, best known outside Japan for his international hit song "Ue o Muite Arukō", which was sung in Japanese and sold over 13 million copies. It reached number one in the United States Billboard Hot 100 in June 1963, making Sakamoto the first Asian recording artist to have a number one song on the chart. Sakamoto died on 12 August 1985 in the crash of Japan

heading: Deaths
txt: Manfred Winkelhock, German race car driver (b. 1951)

heading: Deaths
txt: Evaline Ness, American author and illustrator (b. 1911)

entities.title: Evaline Ness
entities.description:
Evaline Ness was an American commercial artist, illustrator, and author of children's books. She illustrated more than thirty books for young readers and wrote several of her own.
She is noted for using a great variety of artistic media and methods.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Michel Basquiat, American painter (b. 1960)

entities.title: Jean-Michel Basquiat
entities.description: Jean-Michel Basquiat was an American artist who rose to success during the 1980s. Regarded as one of the most influential artists of the 20th century, he was part of the neo-expressionism movement.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Shockley, American physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1910)

entities.title: William Shockley
entities.description: William Bradford Shockley Jr. was an American physicist and inventor. He was the manager of a research group at Bell Labs that included John Bardeen and Walter Brattain. The three scientists were jointly awarded the 1956 Nobel Prize in Physics for "their researches on semiconductors and their discovery of the transistor effect".

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorothy Mackaill, English-American actress (b. 1903)

entities.title: Dorothy Mackaill
entities.description: Dorothy Mackaill was a British-American actress, most active during the silent-film era and into the early 1930s.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Cage, American composer and theorist (b. 1912)

entities.title: John Cage
entities.description: John Milton Cage Jr. was an American composer, music theorist, artist, and philosopher. A pioneer of indeterminacy in music, electroacoustic music, and non-standard use of musical instruments, Cage was one of the leading figures of the post-war avant-garde. Critics have lauded him as one of the most influential composers of the 20th century. He was also instrumental in the development of modern da

heading: Deaths
txt: Victor Ambartsumian, Georgian-Armenian astrophysicist and academic (b. 1908)

entities.title: Victor Ambartsumian
entities.description: Viktor Amazaspovich Ambartsumian was a Soviet Armenian astrophysicist and science administrator. One of the 20th century's top astronomers, he is widely regarded as the founder of theoretical astrophysics in the Soviet Union.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mark Gruenwald, American author and illustrator (b. 1953)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Delano, American photographer and composer (b. 1914)

entities.title: Jack Delano
entities.description: Jack Delano was an American photographer for the Farm Security Administration (FSA), and a composer noted for his use of Puerto Rican folk material.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Drapeau, Canadian lawyer and politician, 37th Mayor of Montreal (b. 1916)

entities.title: Jean Drapeau
entities.description:
Jean Drapeau, was Mayor of Montreal from 1954 to 1957 and 1960 to 1986. 
Major accomplishments of the Drapeau Administration include the development of the Montreal Metro entirely underground mass transit subway system running on 'whisper quiet' rubber wheels, a successful international exposition Expo 67 as well as the construction of a major performing arts centre, the Place des Arts. Drapeau al

entities.title: Mayor of Montreal
entities.description: The Mayor of Montreal is head of the executive branch of the Montreal City Council. The current mayor is Valérie Plante, who was elected into office on November 5, 2017, and sworn in on November 16. The office of the mayor administers all city services, public property, police and fire protection, most public agencies, and enforces all city and provincial laws within Montreal, Quebec. The mayor is

heading: Deaths
txt: Gennady Lyachin, Russian captain (b. 1955)

entities.title: Gennady Lyachin
entities.description: Gennady Petrovich Lyachin was the commanding officer of the Russian submarine Kursk when the vessel suffered a series of explosions and sank on 12 August 2000.

heading: Deaths
txt: Loretta Young, American actress (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Enos Slaughter, American baseball player and manager (b. 1916)

entities.title: Enos Slaughter
entities.description: Enos Bradsher Slaughter, nicknamed "Country", was an American Major League Baseball (MLB) right fielder. He played for 19 seasons on four major league teams from 1938–1942 and 1946–1959. He is noted primarily for his playing for the St. Louis Cardinals and is best known for scoring the winning run in Game 7 of the 1946 World Series. A ten-time All-Star, he has been elected to both the National Bas

heading: Deaths
txt: Godfrey Hounsfield, English biophysicist and engineer, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1919)

entities.title: Godfrey Hounsfield
entities.description: Sir Godfrey Newbold Hounsfield was an English electrical engineer who shared the 1979 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine with Allan MacLeod Cormack for his part in developing the diagnostic technique of X-ray computed tomography (CT).

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Loder, English sound engineer and producer, founded Southern Studios (b. 1946)

entities.title: John Loder (sound engineer)
entities.description: John F. Loder was an English sound engineer, record producer and founder of Southern Studios, as well as a former member of EXIT and co-founder of the Southern Records distribution company with his wife Sue. He was also the studio engineer of choice for Crass and Crass Records, and was often considered to be the band's "ninth member".

entities.title: Southern Studios
entities.description: Southern Studios is a recording studio in the Wood Green area of London. It was founded in 1974 by John Loder, and came to be the recording studio of choice for Crass and their record label Crass Records. Southern Studios Ltd. continues to grow its label and provide label management and distribution services throughout Europe.

heading: Deaths
txt: Victoria Gray Adams, American civil rights activist (b. 1926)

entities.title: Victoria Gray Adams
entities.description: Victoria Jackson Gray Adams was an American civil rights activist from Hattiesburg, Mississippi. She was one of the founding members of the influential Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party.

heading: Deaths
txt: Merv Griffin, American actor, singer, and producer, created Jeopardy! and Wheel of Fortune (b. 1925)

entities.title: Merv Griffin
entities.description: Mervyn Edward Griffin Jr. was an American television show host and media mogul. He began his career as a radio and big band singer who went on to appear in film and on Broadway. From 1965 to 1986, Griffin hosted his own talk show, The Merv Griffin Show. He also created the internationally popular game shows Jeopardy! and Wheel of Fortune through his television production companies, Merv Griffin En

heading: Deaths
txt: Mike Wieringo, American author and illustrator (b. 1963)

heading: Deaths
txt: Christie Allen, English-Australian singer (b. 1954)

entities.title: Christie Allen
entities.description: Christie Allen was an English-born Australian pop singer who had a successful career in Australia. Her top four hits on the Australian Kent Music Report Singles Chart were "Goosebumps" and "He's My Number One". Allen was voted the Most Popular Female Performer at the TV Week / Countdown Music Awards for 1979 and 1980. At the 1979 awards, "Goosebumps" also won the Best Songwriter award for Terry Br

heading: Deaths
txt: Helge Hagerup, Norwegian playwright, poet and novelist (b. 1933)

heading: Deaths
txt: Les Paul, American guitarist and songwriter (b. 1915)

entities.title: Les Paul
entities.description: Lester William Polsfuss, known as Les Paul, was an American jazz, country, and blues guitarist, songwriter, luthier, and inventor. He was one of the pioneers of the solid-body electric guitar, and his prototype, called the Log, served as inspiration for the Gibson Les Paul. Paul taught himself how to play guitar, and while he is mainly known for jazz and popular music, he had an early career in co

heading: Deaths
txt: Isaac Bonewits, American Druid, author, and activist; founded Ár nDraíocht Féin (b. 1949)

entities.title: Isaac Bonewits
entities.description: Phillip Emmons Isaac Bonewits was an American Neo-Druid who published a number of books on the subject of Neopaganism and magic. He was a public speaker, liturgist, singer and songwriter, and founder of the Neopagan organizations Ár nDraíocht Féin and the Aquarian Anti-Defamation League. Born in Royal Oak, Michigan, Bonewits had been heavily involved in occultism since the 1960s.

entities.title: Druid
entities.description: A druid was a member of the high-ranking class in ancient Celtic cultures. Druids were religious leaders as well as legal authorities, adjudicators, lorekeepers, medical professionals and political advisors. Druids left no written accounts. entities.title: President of Malta
entities.description: The President of Malta is the constitutional head of state of Malta. entities.title: The Kubert School
entities.description: The Kubert School, formerly the Joe Kubert School of Cartoon and Graphic Art and Joe Kubert School, is a private, for-profit technical school focused on cartooning and located in Dover, New Jersey. It teaches the principles of sequential art and the particular craft of the comics industry as well as commercial illustration. It is the only accredited school devoted entirely to cartooning.

txt: Lauren Bacall, American model, actress, and singer (b. 1924)

entities.title: Lauren Bacall
entities.description: Lauren Bacall was an American actress. She was named the 20th-greatest female star of classic Hollywood cinema by the American Film Institute and received an Academy Honorary Award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in 2009 in recognition of her contribution to the Golden Age of motion pictures. She was known for her distinctive voice and sultry looks.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Yeoman, American college football player and coach (b. 1927)

entities.title: Bill Yeoman
entities.description: William Frank Yeoman was an American college football player and coach. Starting in 1962, he was the University of Houston's head coach, holding the position through 1986. In his tenure, he became the winningest coach in school history, with an overall record of 160–108–8. Yeoman revolutionized offensive football in 1964 by developing the Veer option offense.
